benchmark_details.name: WIKITABLE QUESTIONS
benchmark_details.overview: A new task and dataset: answering complex questions on semi-structured HTML tables using question-answer pairs as supervision.
benchmark_details.data_type: question-answering pairs (text) on semi-structured HTML tables

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: To evaluate and train semantic parsers that answer complex, compositional questions using semi-structured HTML tables as the knowledge source, learned from question-table-answer triples.
purpose_and_intended_users.limitations: Authors state that 21% of examples cannot be answered using any logical form generated from the current deduction rules. Annotation artifacts and unhandled question types (e.g., yes-no questions, phrases like "same" or "consecutive"), complex cell formats, and incorrect annotations are noted in Section 7.4. Approximately 69% of the questions remain after answer-agreement filtering.

data.source: Randomly selected HTML tables from Wikipedia (tables with at least 8 rows and 5 columns); question-answer pairs authored and validated via Amazon Mechanical Turk.
data.size: 22,033 question-answer pairs on 2,108 HTML tables (20% of tables held out as test set)
data.format: HTML tables (preprocessed: non-textual contents omitted; merged cells unmerged and duplicated into unmerged cells)
data.annotation: Two-stage Amazon Mechanical Turk: (1) workers wrote trivia questions about each table using one of 36 generic prompts; (2) separate workers answered each question based on the table. Answers were kept only if agreed upon by at least two workers; approximately 69% of questions remain after this filtering.

methods: Comparison to baselines (IR baseline, WQ baseline)
Development using three random 80:20 splits of the training data; held-out test tables (20% of tables)
methodology.calculation: Accuracy: number of examples (x,t,y) on which the system outputs the correct answer y. Oracle score: number of examples where at least one generated candidate logical form z in Z_x executes to y.
methodology.interpretation: Accuracy measures final output correctness; oracle score measures whether a correct logical form was generated among candidates (an upper bound on generation coverage).
methodology.baseline_results: On test data: IR baseline accuracy 12.7% (oracle 70.6%), WQ baseline accuracy 24.3% (oracle 35.6%), Our system accuracy 37.1% (oracle 76.6%).
methodology.validation: 20% of tables and their questions set aside as test set. Development used three random 80:20 splits of the remaining training data. Evaluation ensures tables in test do not appear during training.
